9.transcript:
Now, when you start it, ask me how they started getting ready
in the fall for what they would need to use.
9.translation:
Kitak’ ayagceskuvgu
apeksia qaill’ uksuarmi up’ngelauciit atu’urkameggnek.

10.transcript: Will you be sitting like that?

11.transcript: Yes, I will be sitting like this.

12.transcript: Now, how did they get ready for the winter like this?

13.transcript: You mean how people long ago got ready for the fall like this?

17.transcript: And so, I’m not extremely old

18.transcript: But I am now 68 years old.

20.transcript: I have a Yup’ik name, Ackiar, that they called me.

21.transcript: An then when we became Westernized now, they started calling me Nick Lupie.

22.transcript: And so, you just asked how they got ready in the fall

23.transcript: Or, how they got ready for what they would need to use in the winter.

24.transcript: Now, I’m going to start talking, yes, about things I know and have seen.
24.translation:
Wii tua-i nallunrilkemnek tangvallemnek-llu,
yaa, waniw’ qanengssakatartua.

25.transcript: Upriver in Kialiq in the fall like this when we were boys

26.transcript:
Upriver at the mouth of Kialiq,
they say that that creek is called Qukaqlircaraq.
26.translation:
Kiani Kialiim paingani
Qukaqlircaramek-gguq uumek aterluni kuiggaq au͡gna.

28.transcript: Our caretakers here, however, were not sedentary in the fall like this.
28.translation: Makut tau͡gken aulukesteput waten uksuarmi uitaurallrunritut.

29.transcript: Or, they didn’t travel without working like this either.

30.transcript: These things that are used for the fall

31.transcript:
When they came from fish camps across there in the fall,
they would gather wood.
31.translation:
Waten agaaken neqlillernek taigaqameng uksuarmi
muragnek quyurtetullruut.

32.transcript: And they didn’t have boats, only kayaks.

33.transcript: In the morning in the fall like this, because the tide gets very high

34.transcript: They would start traveling in the early morning when it was dark.

35.transcript:
Yet sometimes, a kayak would sometimes come into view
from Cingik downriver.
35.translation: Tua-i tau͡gken iliini uaggun Cingigkun igvarnaurtuq iliini qayaq.

36.transcript: It would be pulling [a cargo of] wood.

37.transcript:
Those people in the fall like this,
when they were going to go to the headwaters of these rivers
37.translation:
Tua-i tamaa-i tamakut waten uksuarmi
maavet kuiget kangritnun ayakata’arqameng

38.transcript: They would gather those when they were going to go to winter camps.

39.transcript: Our elders who raised us were not like how we are here.
39.translation:
Au͡gkut ciuqliput anglicarteput
wangkucicetun maanitun ayuqellrunritut.

40.transcript: They would travel rowing with their own arms

42.transcript: And when it was time, they would start going upriver

43.transcript: Bringing those pieces of wood with them.

44.transcript: And they would then load their possessions on top of them.

45.transcript: Those without boats would relocate using wood.

46.transcript:
And then when they reached the headwaters of those rivers
where they would spend the winter,
they would bring up those pieces of wood.
46.translation:
Tua-i-llu nutaan tekicameng kuiget kangritnun tamaavet uksuillerkameggnun
muriit tamakut tageqluki.

47.transcript:
They would then prepare the wood, preparing their fish traps
that they used to catch fish.
47.translation: Nutaan-llu upluteng muriit tamakut neqsuutekateng taluyarkateng upluki.

48.transcript: Those who raised us back then used to struggle.

49.transcript: They used to prepare that wood to make fish traps, big fish traps.

50.transcript: Big fish traps were like this. Their openings.

52.transcript: And then they were like this.

53.transcript: They called those their inner compartments [ilulirpiit].

54.transcript:
And they would then make fish traps out of the centers too,
inflating them like this.
54.translation: Nutaan-llu ukut cali qukait cali taluyiluki waten qerrurluki.

55.transcript: And they would then put the third over there.

56.transcript: They used to call those old fish traps qamut.

57.transcript: This fish traps were not like, you know, blackfish traps.

58.transcript: You know, they were this far apart.

60.transcript: Yes, they didn’t make those big fish traps haphazardly.
60.translation: Yaa, piciatun-am pivkenaki tamakut taluyarpiit pitullruit.

62.transcript: And then they put that split spruce there.
62.translation: Tua-i-llu imna cigyak elliluku, tuavet elliluku.

63.transcript: And then after doing this over from it

64.transcript: They used to make those big fish traps about this far from each other like this.

65.transcript: When they started working on them like this their hands would become raw.

66.transcript: These parts made like this were not made with twine.
66.translation: Makut ukut waten piurallrit pelacinagnek piyuunaki.

67.transcript: Instead, they thinly split these pieces of wood.
67.translation: Tau͡gaam makunek cali muragnek qupurturluki amililuki, mamkunaki.

68.transcript: They made them about this wide, but thin.
68.translation: Qaillun tua-i waten iqtutaurluki, tau͡gaam amililuki.

69.transcript: They wouldn’t work on those haphazardly either.

71.transcript: When they started doing that, their [hands] here would get raw doing this.
71.translation: Tuaten tua-i pingaqameng makuit nangtullruut ukut waten piurluki.

72.transcript: When they started bleeding, they would wrap these three with hide
72.translation: Aunrangaqata tua-i imkunek qecignek caquliluki ukut pingayun pitullruit

74.transcript: And these, these would also get raw where they held them.

75.transcript: Our ancestors back then were not like this as we are.
75.translation: Au͡gkut, ciuqliput-wa tua-i wangkucicetun waten ayuqellrunritut.

77.transcript: They used wood to make possessions, tools.

78.transcript: They used it for things, houses, possessions for their houses, and sleds.
78.translation: Una cakluki, enekluki, enemeggnun waten aklukluki, ikamraqluki-llu.

79.transcript: They survived using this wood for things.
79.translation: Tua-i cat, aturluku una murak yuungnaqellruut, muriit.

80.transcript: And yet when they started getting set, they would check them every day
80.translation: Tua-i tau͡gken cali civcimariaqamegteki nutaan waten unuaquaqan takuurluki

81.transcript: And they would wake up early in the morning when the tide goes out after it came in.

82.transcript: They would get up at night, [check on] their fishing tools' stakes, go down, and drive them deeper after picking the ice around them like this.

83.transcript: That is what our caretakers back then were like.

84.transcript: They weren't like how it is now.

85.transcript: And then in the fall when it was time.

86.transcript: Their women would prepare tools that they would use.
86.translation: Makut cali arnaita aklukaitnek upluki, atu’urkaitnek.

87.transcript: The skins of these fish, including king salmon
87.translation: Makunek tua-i imkunek neqnek, taryaqviit-llu qeciitnek

88.transcript: They called it preparing fish skins for clothes.

89.transcript: They referred to those fish skins as amiriit.

93.transcript: Those things I just talked about like this
93.translation: Ava-i au͡gna, au͡gkut ava-i waten qanengssakellrenka

94.transcript: Men’s work, how men worked to prepare their tools.
94.translation: Angutet caliarit, angutet calilallrit aklumeggnek upluteng pillret.

96.transcript:
And before it froze like this,
they would prepare tools and skin boots for their men.
96.translation:
Waten cikuvailgan-llu uptenglallruit anguteteng
atu’urkaitnek, pilugugkaitnek.

97.transcript: And these fish skins like this, king salmon [skins]
97.translation: Makunek-llu cali waten neqet qeciitnek, taryaqvagnek

99.transcript: That’s what they would do when they prepared fish skins for clothes.

100.transcript: Also, they wouldn’t just stop at removing the flesh.
100.translation: Cali-am tamakut waten tua-i kemgit au͡g’aqainarraarpek’naki.

101.transcript:
When they were finished removing their flesh,
they wouldn’t work on them right away.
101.translation:
Taqngamegteki tamakut kemgit au͡gaumariaqata
egmianun cali caliaqevkenaki.

102.transcript: They also used to submerge those fish skins into urine like this.
102.translation: Waten cali teq’umun akurrluki pitullruit tamakut neqet qeciit.

103.transcript: They removed the smell of fish.

104.transcript: When they did this, what they called aging urine

105.transcript: Their men would urinate into those containers, their original containers.
105.translation:
Cat, canun tua-i assigtaitnun, nutem assigtaitnun
angutait tamaavet qurrmatullruut.

108.transcript: They used to soak fish skins in those.
108.translation: Tua-i tamakunun akurrluki tamakut neqet qeciit pitullruit.

109.transcript: And after they were soaked, they would then scrape them.

110.transcript: They would scrape them after putting them on boards.

111.transcript: They would then hang them outside to dry.

112.transcript: And then when those dried, they would make those into boots for their men.
112.translation:
Tua-i-llu nutaan kinraki tamakut tamaa-i
tamakunun angutmeggnun piluguliluki.

113.transcript: They called that making them fish skin [clothes] that they would use to travel like this.

116.transcript: When stopped using what they called big fish traps

117.transcript:
When they were going to change those for blackfish too,
they would also make those fish traps.
117.translation:
Makunek maa-i can’giirnek cali cimiqata’arqamegteki
nutaan tamakunek call’ taluyiluteng pitullruut.

118.transcript: And then when they kept them set

119.transcript: These days, we use various things, boxes and sacks to put blackfish in.
119.translation:
Maa-i mat’um nalliini canek can’giiret
waten assigtalaraput piciatun yaassiillernek missuullernek-llu.

120.transcript: However, those who raised us back then that I observed didn’t have those.
120.translation: Tau͡gken au͡gkut murilkellrenka anglicartelput tamakunek pitaitellruut.

121.transcript: Their women also used to prepare grass to put them in.
121.translation: Makut maa-i arnait cali tamakunek canegnek caqukaitnek uptetullruut.

122.transcript: Like this, yes, when they’re not green anymore, when they’re getting pale

123.transcript: They would gather a lot like this.

124.transcript: And in the summer like this...

126.transcript: Women would prepare that grass, coarse grass, for their things.
126.translation: Uptelallruit arnat tamakut pikameggnek tamakut can’get kelugkaitnek.

127.transcript: They would be used for weaving.

128.transcript: Those who raised us back then always kept the future in mind.
128.translation: Au͡gkut anglicartelput ingna tekitarkaq waten umyuaqerrlainarluku pitullruut.

129.transcript:
They always prepared what they would need in the future
even if it was a long way off

131.transcript: They only had what [was made from] the land.
131.translation: Maani tau͡gaam makunek nunam qainganelngurnek aklungqellruut.

132.transcript: They would [work] because they couldn’t afford not to.

133.transcript:
When the need for it was approaching,
they would prepare them a long time beforehand.
133.translation:
Una tua-i tekitarkaurtaqan pissuutekaa una
yaaqsigluk’ amna upyutaqluki.

134.transcript: They also used to use tall cottongrass from the summer for weaving.
134.translation: Kiagmi maa-i iitaat can’get kelugkaqluki pitullruit.

135.transcript:
When women started gathering those tall cottongrass,
they would spread them to dry, nalacirluki as they called it.
135.translation:
Arnat iitartaangaqameng tamakunek
tua-i-llu nutaan saggluki waten apeqmeggnek nalacirluki.

136.transcript: And then when those had dried, nalaluteng as they say,
136.translation: Tua-i-llu nutaan tamakunek piameng apeqmeggnek naliita, kinraki

137.transcript: They wouldn’t gather them either, [but] weave them.

138.transcript: And then when they finished them, they would roll them up.

139.transcript: That’s what they used to do with grass that they used for weaving.

140.transcript: These days, when I think about those people back then
140.translation: Au͡gkut ava-i wangkuta mat’um nalliini-w’ tua-i umyuaqaqamki

141.transcript: I’ve started becoming daunted about leading that kind of life.

142.transcript: And then when the men [worked on] their tools.

143.transcript: They would make mink traps that looked like fish traps.

144.transcript: They made them small, about this long, and something like this.
144.translation: Mikluki tua-i, qaill’ waten taktaurluki, qaillun-llu tua-i waten.

145.transcript: They would make traps depending on the creeks.

146.transcript:
Those weren’t made haphazardly either.
They also had [set] measurements.
146.translation:
Tamakut-am cali piciatun pivkenateng.
Cuqerluteng cali.

147.transcript:
Their inner compartments were not like blackfish traps either.
They would be like this.
147.translation:
Makut-llu cali ilulirait waten can’giircuutetun ayuqevkenateng.
Waten pinaurtut.

148.transcript: And then that part over there would be like a den.

149.transcript: When I watched my older sister’s husband like this
149.translation: Au͡gna-wa alqerma uinga tayima waten tangvaurarqamni

150.transcript: He would do this with his hands to measure the entrance
150.translation: Unatni tua-i waten piqerluki tauna tua-i cuq’errluku iteryararkaa

151.transcript: Doing that to what they called the throat.

152.transcript:
That’s what they were like.
They weren’t haphazard.

153.transcript: And then when he made otter traps like fish traps

154.transcript: Their entrances would be like this as before.

155.transcript:
And then he would do this, measuring it with his thumb,
determining the width like this.
155.translation:
Tua-i-llu waten unatni cuq’errluku uumek kumluminek
waten elliurluki neqututacirkiurluki.

156.transcript:
Like that.
Yes, they apparently didn’t make those haphazardly either.
156.translation:
Tuaten.
Yaa, piciatun-am cali pivkenateng tamakut pitullrulliniut.

157.transcript: These days, when I think about them back then
157.translation: Tua-i mat’um nalliini-w’ tua-i umyuaqaqamki au͡gkut

158.transcript: I wonder how their lives were.

159.transcript: When I think of them, I would be daunted [by their lives].

160.transcript: But because I [was born] when they started becoming Westernized

161.transcript: Our caretakers occasionally had Western things

162.transcript: But they didn’t get a lot.

163.transcript: They would get tea, flour, sugar, and pilot bread once in a blue moon.
163.translation:
Makut maa-i saayut, mukaaq, saarralaq,
caqapigtaqameng-llu sugg’alinek cali piaqluteng.

164.transcript: And yet those things that they got

165.transcript: They would smell very strong when they were brought in.

166.transcript: And they don’t [seem to] have any scent these days.

167.transcript:
When they took out the pilot bread, they smell strong from afar,
they smelled nice and delicious.
167.translation:
Sugg’alit antaqaceteng yaaqsigluteng tepsaqnaurtut
narniqpiarluteng, assirluteng.

168.transcript: These days, I can’t [smell] them anymore.
168.translation: Maa-i mat’um nalliini waten caciirulluki wiinga piunga.

169.transcript: Once in a while, though, I smell them when they’re close.

170.transcript: That’s what those people back then were like.

171.transcript:
So, how about, you know, admonishments when the men,
you know, when they traveled in the fall like this?
171.translation: Qaillun-mi uksuarmi iciw’ waten ayagaqata iciw’ inerquutek’lallrit angutet?

172.transcript:
And so, yes, they used to admonish them like this
when it was dangerous as they traveled.
172.translation: Tua-llu, ii-i, waten ayagaaqameng inerquutektullruit waten aarnarqellrani.

173.transcript: They also used to tell them not to make a lot of noise in the wilderness.

174.transcript: They said not to make a lot of noise like this.

175.transcript: Only those who get into accidents

176.transcript: They must make noise if they have an fall into the water.

177.transcript:
They also admonished us against yelling in the wilderness
in the fall like this.
177.translation: Inerquutekluki-am cali tamakut waten uksuarmi yuilqumi aarasqevkenata.

178.transcript: They told us not to make a lot of noise.

179.transcript:
They said that only those in dire situations
would make noise like that.
179.translation: Tamakut-gguq tamaa-i tau͡gaam nanikualriit tuaten nepliratullruut.

180.transcript:
And then if they heard anyone screaming, making noise,
they would understand that [s]he’s gotten into an accident or fell into water.
180.translation:
Tua-i-llu neplialriamek aaralriamek niiskuneng
tua-i tauna taringarkauluku arenqiallugucia wall’u kis’ucia.

181.transcript:
Yet because they are not admonished anymore these days,
they don’t know [those] anymore because we don’t admonish youpl.
181.translation:
Tau͡gken mat’um nalliini tua-i inerquumananriameng-wa tua-i,
inerqurnanriamceci wangkuta caciirulluteng.

182.transcript: They also make noise like this.

183.transcript: They yell in between villages here.

184.transcript: They used to admonish against those.

185.transcript:
And then, I’ve done that once
when I heard someone who got into an accident.
185.translation:
Tua-i-llu ataucirqumek wiinga atullruaqa tamana
arenqiallugtellria niitellemni.

186.transcript: Before it was too long since Tuntutuliak was established as a village

187.transcript: When we were down in Kelliq, with people inland from us too.
187.translation: Kellirni kanani uitallemteńi, ukut-wa keluqliput cali.

188.transcript: You see this lake toward the water from this house.
188.translation: Una waniwa nanvaq mat’um enem ketiini tangrran.

189.transcript:
In the day nearing evening like this,
I heard someone screaming inland from us.
189.translation: Waten erenrani atakuyartumi maaken kelumteńek aaralria.

190.transcript: I had thought it was the people inland.

191.transcript:
It turned out that someone fell into the water down there.
[S]he had apparently fell into the water.

192.transcript:
One of the people going down apparently saw the person
just as [s]he was going to freeze to death

193.transcript: When there was no land here like this.

194.transcript: They had a lot of admonishments back then.

195.transcript: They used to tell them like this not to make a lot of noise.

196.transcript: And then this was especially important:

197.transcript:
When they’re going to travel, they would always say
that they’re going around that area.
197.translation:
Ayakata’arqameng cali qanerrlainarluteng
tamatum nuniinun ayakatarniluteng.

198.transcript: And when they didn’t return, they would know where they had accidents.
198.translation: Tua-i waten tekitenritaqata-llu tua-i arenqialluguciit nalluvkenaki piaqluki.

199.transcript:
Yet these days, when they travel like this with these boats,
they don’t say anything.
199.translation:
Tau͡gken mat’um nalliini waten ayagaaqameng
maa-i angyatgun qanerpek’nateng.

200.transcript:
And then when they don’t return, they don’t know what happened to them
because they didn’t say anything.
200.translation:
Tua-i-llu tekitenrilameng, tekitenrilata qaill’ tua-i ayuquciinaki
qanenrilata.

201.transcript: It’s because they’ve started traveling without consideration these days.

202.transcript: Or they pretend to go somewhere then travel to other villages.

203.transcript: That’s what’s making us so addled these days.
203.translation: Tamaa-i tamatum maa-i mat’um nalliini ayuquciirutetaitkut.

204.transcript:
They have no idea about these descendants like this
or they think they’re in some place.
204.translation:
Qaillun tua-i ukut kingunrulriit waten ayuquciinaki piaqluki
wall’u tuancukluki.

205.transcript:
These days, even when they die in the wilderness,
they have no idea about them.
205.translation: Maa-i mat’um nalliini yuilqumi-llu tua-i tuqungraata qaillun ayuquciitaqluki.

206.transcript: You see, because there are now a lot of things bringing struggles these days
206.translation: Tang tua-i mat’um nalliini tua-i-wa waten caknernarqellriit amlleriameng

207.transcript: People back then were not like this, like this.

209.transcript: And in the fall, they would always talk to us boys like this
209.translation: Uksuarmi-llu wangkuta cali tan’gaurlurni waten qalaruquratullruitkut

210.transcript: About our futures, what’s in store for us, that they are experiencing.

211.transcript: They would indicate what was dangerous, in the wilderness too.

212.transcript: These things on land, elevated hills, had names.
212.translation: Cat, cat-llu maani nunam qaingani pengurraat qerturalriit aterluteng.

213.transcript: All of the creeks had names too.

214.transcript: Some of the lakes had names too.

215.transcript: They knew the layout of this land.

216.transcript: Yet these days, because we don’t point those out to our children
216.translation: Tau͡gken mat’um nalliini makut maa-i yup’ut apertuatnanriamteki

217.transcript:
They don’t know the wilderness or what’s on it,
rivers, and lakes, and these elevated areas.
217.translation:
Mat’umek yuilqumek cat-llu nallungluki,
kuiget-llu, nanvat-llu, qertulriit-llu makut.

218.transcript:
And when something happens,
when we ask them where it happened to them
218.translation: Camek-llu tua-i piaqata apcaaqellriani cam nuniini camek piciitnek

219.transcript: Or a person these days would get lost, they get lost.
219.translation: Wall’u yuk tauna waten maa-i mat’um nalliini tamarilalriit, tamalalriit.

220.transcript:
When they ask the people who saw it about the area where they saw it
they don’t know its name either.
220.translation:
Tauna, tauna tangertellra apcaaqellriani cam nuniini tangellrucianek
atra-llu nalluluku.

221.transcript:
They would say it happened over there
because we don’t point those out to them anymore.

222.transcript: We used to talk about everything, but we didn’t always experience them.
222.translation:
Ca tamalkuan wangkuta qalaruyutek’lallruyaaqaput
aturrlainarpek’naki tau͡gaam.

223.transcript: But when we reached them, we would recognize them.

224.transcript: Yes, a person should live through traditional wisdom.

225.transcript:
Yes, [s]he evidently will not live well
if [s]he does not adhere to traditional wisdom.

226.transcript: [S]he will also lack what their peers work on.

227.transcript: They used to tell us this back then:

228.transcript:
If we adhere to this traditional wisdom, obey it while we live
we will live well.
228.translation:
Man’a-gguq qanruyun atuqumteggu, maligtaquluku-llu yuukumta
elluarrluta yuugarkaugukut.

229.transcript: We should not be lazy or sleep too much.

231.transcript: However, yes, we wouldn’t reach what they indicated yet.
231.translation: Tau͡gken tua-i, yaa, taman’ apertuallrat tekiteksaunaku.

232.transcript: But when we reach it these days, we recognize it.
232.translation: Tau͡gaam tekitaqamteggu maa-i mat’um nalliini elitaqaqluku.

233.transcript: That’s why they used to tell us this back then:

234.transcript:
They said to pay attention to our instructor
yes, we should watch his mouth.
234.translation:
Una-gguq qalarutestevvut murilkelluku,
yaa, tangvaurqilarput qanra.

235.transcript:
They said that if we look away from him,
[we] won’t know what he’s talking about anymore.
